abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Roads Project
            for Sri Lanka was marginally satisfactory. The project did
            not fully achieve its objectives, its impact on
            institutional development was modest, sustainability is
            likely, and both the Bank and Borrower performed
            satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, it is important during appraisal to take the
            time necessary to ensure that institutional arrangements are
            adequate to implement the project. Second, accurate
            estimates of civil works costs require thorough inspections
            and condition surveys during identification and appraisal.
            Third, consultant engineers and economists preparing project
            designs and costs cannot be relied upon to deliver
            appropriate and accurate products without a thorough review
            by the Bank and Borrower. Fourth, when the implementing
            agency is inexperienced in dealing with international
            contractors and large contracts, the supervisory role for
            the Bank substantially increases. Fifth, the use of
            standardized bidding documents should be mandated to limit
            bidding problems and contractor claims. Finally, technology
            transfers work best when counterpart staff are expressly
            assigned to the project from its inception and continuity is assured.
